Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Information security pertains to the security of digital and non-digital hardcopy data.

***)

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) only refers to email addresses.

***)

Encryption is a way of unlocking data without needing a password.

***)

Any data you have access to should be considered public.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Correct

Information security refers to how we defend our computer systems and information in digital and hardcopy format.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Information security refers to how we defend our computer systems and information in digital and hardcopy format.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Information security refers to how we defend our computer systems and information in digital and hardcopy format.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Information security refers to how we defend our computer systems and information in digital and hardcopy format.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is an example of PII?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Your Bank Account number.

***)

Office financial records.

***)

Strategies, plans, and internal processes.

***)

Encrypted files.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Correct

Personally Identifiable Information, or PII, is any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred. In this case, your Bank Account number is PII, because it provides enough information to identify you.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Personally Identifiable Information, or PII, is any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred. In this case, your Bank Account number is PII, because it provides enough information to identify you.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Personally Identifiable Information, or PII, is any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred. In this case, your Bank Account number is PII, because it provides enough information to identify you.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Personally Identifiable Information, or PII, is any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred. In this case, your Bank Account number is PII, because it provides enough information to identify you.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Simply clicking on a link in a phishing email won't infect your computer with malware.

***)

Phishing only occurs via email or email attachment.

***)

Reputable banks often send email messages requesting personal information.

***)

It's a best practice to navigate to your bank or other website by typing in the website address rather than clicking a link from an email message.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. By navigating to your bank's official website, you will avoid clicking on a possibly infected link in an email message that appears to come from your bank.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. By navigating to your bank's official website, you will avoid clicking on a possibly infected link in an email message that appears to come from your bank.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. By navigating to your bank's official website, you will avoid clicking on a possibly infected link in an email message that appears to come from your bank.

CONTINUE

Correct

By navigating to your bank's official website, you will avoid clicking on a possibly infected link in an email message that appears to come from your bank.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Social engineering refers to best practices for accessing social media at work.

***)

Social engineering occurs when you open a web link that is infected with a virus.

***)

Social engineering is usually done through email.

***)

A social engineer might try to build a rapport with you by finding common interests and then asking you for a "favor."

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Social engineers are experts at deception and will use tactics, such as finding common interests to trick you into divulging sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Social engineers are experts at deception and will use tactics, such as finding common interests to trick you into divulging sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Social engineers are experts at deception and will use tactics, such as finding common interests to trick you into divulging sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Correct

Social engineers are experts at deception and will use tactics, such as finding common interests to trick you into divulging sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: What should you do if you need to install an application to your computer?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Install the application and then let your supervisor know.

***)

Get proper approval and instructions on how to proceed.

***)

Install the application as long as you trust the site that hosts the download link.

***)

See if you can get a copy of the application from a coworker.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Get approval before installing any application on your computer.

CONTINUE

Correct

Get approval before installing any application on your computer.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Get approval before installing any application on your computer.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Get approval before installing any application on your computer.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is a common technique a malicious insider might use to gain access to confidential information?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Contacting you by phone and trying to get you to take a survey.

***)

Rummaging through your desk to find your password.

***)

Installing malware through phishing.

***)

Using spyware to steal files from the network.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. In addition to rummaging through your desk to find your password or other confidential information, a malicious insider might also try to use your computer to access the network when you are not around, read incoming and outgoing faxes, and even go through the garbage looking for sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Correct

In addition to rummaging through your desk to find your password or other confidential information, a malicious insider might also try to use your computer to access the network when you are not around, read incoming and outgoing faxes, and even go through the garbage looking for sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. In addition to rummaging through your desk to find your password or other confidential information, a malicious insider might also try to use your computer to access the network when you are not around, read incoming and outgoing faxes, and even go through the garbage looking for sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. In addition to rummaging through your desk to find your password or other confidential information, a malicious insider might also try to use your computer to access the network when you are not around, read incoming and outgoing faxes, and even go through the garbage looking for sensitive information.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Securing information includes ensuring you've saved it anywhere you might need to access it.

***)

Examples of confidential data include annual reports, website content, and press releases.

***)

Loss of public data could lead to financial harm or harm to our reputation.

***)

Electronic confidential information must be secured with encryption when it is stored or transmitted.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Encryption, which is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it, should be used to secure electronic confidential data.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Encryption, which is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it, should be used to secure electronic confidential data.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Encryption, which is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it, should be used to secure electronic confidential data.

CONTINUE

Correct

Encryption, which is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it, should be used to secure electronic confidential data.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is a best practice for using a mobile device to store workplace information?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Only use mobile devices that you own, because you can download any app you need.

***)

Store sensitive data on your mobile device as a backup.

***)

Remove workplace information when it is no longer needed.

***)

Use the same password for all of your mobile devices.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Of the answer options, the only best practice is to remove workplace information when it is no longer needed. The other answer options are not best practices and could leave our organization vulnerable to hackers.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Of the answer options, the only best practice is to remove workplace information when it is no longer needed. The other answer options are not best practices and could leave our organization vulnerable to hackers.

CONTINUE

Correct

Of the answer options, the only best practice is to remove workplace information when it is no longer needed. The other answer options are not best practices and could leave our organization vulnerable to hackers.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Of the answer options, the only best practice is to remove workplace information when it is no longer needed. The other answer options are not best practices and could leave our organization vulnerable to hackers.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

You do not need to get pre-approval to access workplace information as long as you're using your own computer.

***)

You should use whatever public Wi-Fi connection is available to you.

***)

You should avoid discussing confidential information over the phone or displaying confidential information on computer screens in public places, such as airports or cafes.

***)

It's only OK to dispose of hardcopy confidential information by throwing it in the garbage if you're outside of the workplace.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Always keep in mind that eavesdroppers might listen in on your conversations, especially in public places, therefore you should avoid discussing confidential information over the phone or displaying it on a laptop.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Always keep in mind that eavesdroppers might listen in on your conversations, especially in public places, therefore you should avoid discussing confidential information over the phone or displaying it on a laptop.

CONTINUE

Correct

Always keep in mind that eavesdroppers might listen in on your conversations, especially in public places, therefore you should avoid discussing confidential information over the phone or displaying it on a laptop.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Always keep in mind that eavesdroppers might listen in on your conversations, especially in public places, therefore you should avoid discussing confidential information over the phone or displaying it on a laptop.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: In addition to email, what other method might a phisher use to trick you into installing malware?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Search a shared meeting area.

***)

Steal a mobile device.

***)

SMS text messages.

***)

Call you pretending to be a vendor.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Phishing can occur over any kind of electronic communication, including email, SMS text messages, and IM.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Phishing can occur over any kind of electronic communication, including email, SMS text messages, and IM.

CONTINUE

Correct

Phishing can occur over any kind of electronic communication, including email, SMS text messages, and IM.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Phishing can occur over any kind of electronic communication, including email, SMS text messages, and IM.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: While at your desk, a woman approaches you wearing a known and trusted vendor identification badge. She says she needs to login into your computer to check your network connection. What should you do?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Quiz her about company information to see if she answers correctly.

***)

Give her access to your computer, but follow up with a supervisor later.

***)

Give her access to your computer, but watch her carefully.

***)

Check with your supervisor before giving her any access to your system.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. This is an example of a social engineering attack. You should contact your supervisor prior to allowing any access to your system.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. This is an example of a social engineering attack. You should contact your supervisor prior to allowing any access to your system.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. This is an example of a social engineering attack. You should contact your supervisor prior to allowing any access to your system.

CONTINUE

Correct

This is an example of a social engineering attack. You should contact your supervisor prior to allowing any access to your system.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Doors to sensitive locations should remain unlocked to allow for easy access.

***)

You should lend your badge to any coworkers who may have forgotten theirs.

***)

Printers, copiers, and fax machines often have hard drives that must be physically wiped clean before being disposed of.

***)

You should share your computer and Internet access to important visitors.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Printers, copiers, and fax machines might have sensitive data stored on their hard drives, which must be destroyed before disposal of the device.

The correct response is ***. Printers, copiers, and fax machines might have sensitive data stored on their hard drives, which must be destroyed before disposal of the device.

CONTINUE

Correct

Printers, copiers, and fax machines might have sensitive data stored on their hard drives, which must be destroyed before disposal of the device.

CONTINUE

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Printers, copiers, and fax machines might have sensitive data stored on their hard drives, which must be destroyed before disposal of the device.

CONTINUE

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is TRUE?

Answers.Answer:
***)

It is a best practice to open suspicious emails to check them for malware.

***)

You should install applications that you need by downloading them from their official websites.

***)

Web browser add-ons, such as Adobe Flash and Oracle JAVA, can be a source of malware infections.

***)

Antivirus software protects you from unwittingly cooperating with malware.

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. You should disable certain browser plugins, such as Flash, Acrobat, or JAVA, if you don't really need them.

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following is a strong password best practice?

Answers.Answer:
***)

Use a maximum of 6 characters.

***)

Use all uppercase letters.

***)

Include punctuation, such as "?," ";," and "&."

***)

Use a piece of personal information, so you'll more easily remember it.

Rules.Rule:
Please Try Again

Please select your answer.

Click the blue "Continue" button to proceed.

Incorrect

The correct response is ***. Including punctuation in a password will help protect it from password cracker programs.

Including punctuation in a password will help protect it from password cracker programs.

Answers.Answer:
***)

You should report a lost or stolen mobile device within one week of the device going lost.

***)

If your device contains workplace information, never connect it to an unsecured wireless connection.

***)

You do not need prior approval to store confidential information as long as you're using your own mobile device.

Only download software updates for mobile devices when it is absolutely necessary, no more than quarterly.

Only use mobile devices that you own, because you can download any app you need.

Store sensitive data on your mobile device as a backup.

Remove workplace information when it is no longer needed.

Use the same password for all of your mobile devices.

Rummaging through your desk to find your password.
